ContentDescription: Investigate the ways in which drama and theatre artists across cultures, times, places and other contexts use the elements of drama, expressive and performance skills, conventions of performance styles and design areas to represent, communicate and challenge ideas and perspectives
Elaboration: Identifying and discussing the use of elements of drama in a production or performance by professional artists or by peers; for example, using viewpoints to develop questions such as ‘What did I see, hear and feel in the drama?’, ‘How did the actors make the characters believable?’, ‘When was the drama set?’ and ‘What was the purpose of the drama?’

ContentDescription: Investigate the ways in which drama and theatre artists across cultures, times, places and other contexts use the elements of drama, expressive and performance skills, conventions of performance styles and design areas to represent, communicate and challenge ideas and perspectives
Elaboration: Exploring drama and theatre from other cultures, places and times, and discussing how the use of elements and conventions might contribute to their own drama-making and theatre production

ContentDescription: Investigate the ways in which drama and theatre artists across cultures, times, places and other contexts use the elements of drama, expressive and performance skills, conventions of performance styles and design areas to represent, communicate and challenge ideas and perspectives
Elaboration: Exploring how cultural understandings communicate meaning in drama; for example, exploring how drama is used to share cultural knowledge in celebrations, ceremonies or rituals that happen in their local community or in another place or culture

ContentDescription: Investigate the ways in which drama and theatre artists across cultures, times, places and other contexts use the elements of drama, expressive and performance skills, conventions of performance styles and design areas to represent, communicate and challenge ideas and perspectives
Elaboration: Communicating meaning through realistic and non-realistic performance styles and forms by manipulating the elements of drama, performance skills and design areas

ContentDescription: Investigate the ways in which drama and theatre artists across cultures, times, places and other contexts use the elements of drama, expressive and performance skills, conventions of performance styles and design areas to represent, communicate and challenge ideas and perspectives
Elaboration: Establishing aspects of the dramatic action as symbolic, such as a suitcase representing a person’s memories or a light symbolising hope

ContentDescription: Investigate the ways in which drama and theatre artists across cultures, times, places and other contexts use the elements of drama, expressive and performance skills, conventions of performance styles and design areas to represent, communicate and challenge ideas and perspectives
Elaboration: Exploring the implied or underlying aspects of characters, such as their motives and intentions

ContentDescription: Investigate the ways in which drama, including work created and/or performed by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples, celebrates and challenges multiple perspectives of Australian identity
Elaboration: Exploring how performances that tell stories maintain culture, for example narrative drama that communicates knowledge about land, sea, sky or waterways

ContentDescription: Investigate the ways in which drama, including work created and/or performed by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples, celebrates and challenges multiple perspectives of Australian identity
Elaboration: Exploring scripts written by a variety of playwrights including those by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples

ContentDescription: Investigate the ways in which drama, including work created and/or performed by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples, celebrates and challenges multiple perspectives of Australian identity
Elaboration: Identifying and discussing the role of storytelling in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural traditions, through direct engagement with community, Elders and artists or using online resources created or co-created by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples

ContentDescription: Experiment with ways to combine the elements of drama, expressive and performance skills and design areas to construct dramatic meaning for audience in improvisations, devised drama and scripted drama
Elaboration: Using viewpoints to ask questions that explore how specific cultures manipulate the elements of drama, such as ‘How does our own cultural identity impact our understanding of meaning in drama?’ and ‘How do we understand the artistic practices of various cultures?’

ContentDescription: Experiment with ways to combine the elements of drama, expressive and performance skills and design areas to construct dramatic meaning for audience in improvisations, devised drama and scripted drama
Elaboration: Imagining and developing a ‘new scene’ to include in a dramatic retelling of a known narrative

ContentDescription: Experiment with ways to combine the elements of drama, expressive and performance skills and design areas to construct dramatic meaning for audience in improvisations, devised drama and scripted drama
Elaboration: Experimenting with creating characters and what insights and perspectives can emerge

ContentDescription: Experiment with ways to combine the elements of drama, expressive and performance skills and design areas to construct dramatic meaning for audience in improvisations, devised drama and scripted drama
Elaboration: Experimenting with the elements of drama and conventions of styles that explore different actor–audience relationships, for example children’s theatre, theatre of cruelty, theatre in the round, physical theatre, immersive theatre or epic theatre

ContentDescription: Experiment with ways to combine the elements of drama, expressive and performance skills and design areas to construct dramatic meaning for audience in improvisations, devised drama and scripted drama
Elaboration: Annotating a script excerpt, making notes about meaning and intention and what is happening in the excerpt

ContentDescription: Experiment with ways to combine the elements of drama, expressive and performance skills and design areas to construct dramatic meaning for audience in improvisations, devised drama and scripted drama
Elaboration: Using improvisation or working with script to compare different ways that improvised and scripted drama can create characters and action

ContentDescription: Reflect on, analyse. evaluate and document their own and others’ drama work to inform choices and interpretations made both as artists and as audiences
Elaboration: Maintaining a portfolio of design ideas, stimulus images, extracts from scripts and reviews of theatre to inform choices and interpretations

ContentDescription: Reflect on, analyse. evaluate and document their own and others’ drama work to inform choices and interpretations made both as artists and as audiences
Elaboration: Maintaining a journal that reflects on the processes of creating a solo or ensemble work

ContentDescription: Reflect on, analyse. evaluate and document their own and others’ drama work to inform choices and interpretations made both as artists and as audiences
Elaboration: Engaging in class discussion to analyse and evaluate a theatre performance including the acting, direction and application of design areas

ContentDescription: Reflect on, analyse. evaluate and document their own and others’ drama work to inform choices and interpretations made both as artists and as audiences
Elaboration: Writing a review of a performance that evaluates the effectiveness of some of the choices

ContentDescription: Reflect on, analyse. evaluate and document their own and others’ drama work to inform choices and interpretations made both as artists and as audiences
Elaboration: Discussing how viewing professional performances and productions enhances their own work

ContentDescription: Reflect on, analyse. evaluate and document their own and others’ drama work to inform choices and interpretations made both as artists and as audiences
Elaboration: Evaluating drama they experience in live performance and considering how they can use specific techniques in their own work

ContentDescription: Create drama and produce theatre for audiences using narrative and non-narrative forms, elements of drama and style-specific conventions to communicate ideas, meaning and intention
Elaboration: Using viewpoints to ask questions when exploring character, such as ‘How did the performers use the elements of drama and design elements effectively?’, ‘How did the actors show status and motivation through the application of their expressive and performance skills?’ and ‘What was the intended effect on the audience?’

ContentDescription: Create drama and produce theatre for audiences using narrative and non-narrative forms, elements of drama and style-specific conventions to communicate ideas, meaning and intention
Elaboration: Asking evaluative questions, such as ‘How can we use the elements of drama to convey ideas?’, ‘How can we manipulate materials in our drama?’, ‘How can our director and performers shape skills and processes to make and communicate meaning?’ and ‘How are we using design areas?’

ContentDescription: Create drama and produce theatre for audiences using narrative and non-narrative forms, elements of drama and style-specific conventions to communicate ideas, meaning and intention
Elaboration: Varying the use of voice techniques such as projection, dynamics, pace, pause and pitch to create and communicate characters’ intentions

ContentDescription: Create drama and produce theatre for audiences using narrative and non-narrative forms, elements of drama and style-specific conventions to communicate ideas, meaning and intention
Elaboration: Exploring how movement and gesture contrast with stillness and silence to communicate mood

ContentDescription: Create drama and produce theatre for audiences using narrative and non-narrative forms, elements of drama and style-specific conventions to communicate ideas, meaning and intention
Elaboration: Collaborating, rehearsing and negotiating with others to interpret scripts and explore story, characters and conflict

ContentDescription: Create drama and produce theatre for audiences using narrative and non-narrative forms, elements of drama and style-specific conventions to communicate ideas, meaning and intention
Elaboration: Devising drama based on research or knowledge about a project happening in their school or local community to encourage cultural awareness or to present different perspectives, for example a social or environmental issue

ContentDescription: Apply design areas to both devised and scripted works to enhance meaning for an intended audience
Elaboration: Exploring the impact of design areas on dramatic meaning through application of costumes, props, sound, lighting and technologies

ContentDescription: Apply design areas to both devised and scripted works to enhance meaning for an intended audience
Elaboration: Analysing and evaluating a design area and its specific intention in a devised work or the interpretation of a script

ContentDescription: Apply design areas to both devised and scripted works to enhance meaning for an intended audience
Elaboration: Analysing the application of a design area and its impact on an audience

ContentDescription: Apply design areas to both devised and scripted works to enhance meaning for an intended audience
Elaboration: Working collaboratively to develop a cohesive design concept to interpret a script excerpt

ContentDescription: Apply design areas to both devised and scripted works to enhance meaning for an intended audience
Elaboration: Researching and documenting design options in a design portfolio

ContentDescription: Apply design areas to both devised and scripted works to enhance meaning for an intended audience
Elaboration: Sourcing sustainable materials deliberately to apply design areas in the creation of devised work or the interpretation of a script

ContentDescription: Plan, rehearse, refine, present and perform improvised, devised and scripted drama in different contexts to a range of audiences in a range of spaces
Elaboration: Using props, costumes and available technologies such as light, sound or multimedia to create symbol and enhance dramatic meaning

ContentDescription: Plan, rehearse, refine, present and perform improvised, devised and scripted drama in different contexts to a range of audiences in a range of spaces
Elaboration: Focusing on communication with the audience, for example by remembering lines, movements and cues in rehearsal and performance

ContentDescription: Plan, rehearse, refine, present and perform improvised, devised and scripted drama in different contexts to a range of audiences in a range of spaces
Elaboration: Showing understanding of the purpose of rehearsing and the need for collaboration when presenting drama and theatre

ContentDescription: Plan, rehearse, refine, present and perform improvised, devised and scripted drama in different contexts to a range of audiences in a range of spaces
Elaboration: Experimenting with actor–audience relationships and making choices that relate to conventions and conveying intended meaning

ContentDescription: Plan, rehearse, refine, present and perform improvised, devised and scripted drama in different contexts to a range of audiences in a range of spaces
Elaboration: Sharing ideas about their drama with audiences, for example through choice of performance space, approach to entering or leaving the performance space, pre-show presentations or creating an introduction to their work, such as a podcast
